title: Trump names Robert O'Brien, hostage negotiator, as national security adviser
text:
President Trump on Wednesday said he’s selected Robert C. O’Brien, his main hostage negotiator, as his national security adviser.

Mr. O’Brien will replace John R. Bolton, who was ousted last week amid disagreements with key White House aides and Mr. Trump on topics such as Iran, North Korea and Venezuela.

“He’s worked with me for quite a while now on hostages, and we have a tremendous track record on hostages,” Mr. Trump said of Mr. O’Brien, who served as U.S. special presidential envoy for hostage affairs.

“Robert has been fantastic. We know each other well,” Mr. Trump told reporters during an appearance with Mr. O’Brien in Los Angeles.

Mr. O’ Brien called it a “privilege” to serve.

“We’ve got a number of challenges,” he said.

Indeed, Mr. O’Brien was named as national security adviser as the president weighs a response to Iran’s alleged role in drone attacks that crippled Saudi oil production over the weekend.

Mr. O’Brien will be called into action immediately, as Mr. Trump heads to New York for the U.N. General Assembly next week.

“Robert’s a very experienced foreign policy figure with deep knowledge of United Nations, international organizations,” said Nile Gardiner, director of the Margaret Thatcher Center for Freedom at The Heritage Foundation, and who worked alongside Mr. O’Brien on Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential bid. “I think there will be a lot of U.N.-related work in the coming year on many fronts, not least of which with Iran, North Korea.”

Mr. O’Brien worked under President George W. Bush as a representative to the U.N., continuing in Mr. Bolton’s footsteps as a Trump official with connections to the last GOP administration.

Mr. Trump has tired of previous Bush veterans — beyond Mr. Bolton, there was Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, who sparred with Mr. Trump over immigration before her ouster.

Still, Mr. Gardiner said Mr. O’Brien offers solid ground to the president.

“He’s a safe pair of hands,” he said. “He’s somebody who, I think, has very good instincts, and a very good understanding of the challenges facing the United States as leader of the free world.”

Mr. O’Brien endeared himself to Mr. Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo by working to secure the release of Pastor Andrew Brunson from Turkey, Americans held in Afghanistan and Danny Burch, an oil worker held in Yemen for 18 months.

Mr. Trump hailed Mr. O’Brien’s work in a welcome-home ceremony for Mr. Burch in the Oval Office in March.

In turn, Mr. O’Brien praised Mr. Trump for working to bring home Americans through “force of will,” without concessions or payments.

Mr. O’Brien will be the president’s fourth national security adviser in less than three years.

His first, Michael Flynn, was an Army lieutenant general and key campaign surrogate for Mr. Trump.

He was ousted after just weeks on the job for misleading Vice President Mike Pence over contacts with the Russian ambassador to the U.S. He then pleaded guilty to lying to investigators about those contacts as part of special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation.

His replacement, H.R. McMaster, lasted for a while but Mr. Trump tired of him by early 2018 and tapped Mr. Bolton instead, though his relationship with Mr. Bolton soured beyond repair this year.
